title: Leptomeningeal Carcinomatosis (Leptomeningeal Metastases)
icd10: ** C79.32 (Secondary malignant neoplasm of cerebral meninges)
C79.49 (Secondary malignant neoplasm of other parts of nervous system)
C79.31 (Secondary malignant neoplasm of brain — if concurrent parenchymal metastases)
scope: ** Comprehensive management of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis in adults from common solid tumors (breast cancer, non-small cell lung cancer, melanoma) and hematologic malignancies (lymphoma, leukemia). Covers initial evaluation and stabilization, CSF diagnosis (cytology, flow cytometry, cell-free DNA), neuroimaging (gadolinium-enhanced MRI brain and spine), intrathecal chemotherapy (methotrexate, cytarabine, thiotepa) via lumbar puncture or Ommaya reservoir, systemic therapy with CNS penetration, radiation therapy (involved-field, whole-brain, craniospinal), management of hydrocephalus (VP shunt, ETV), steroid management, seizure treatment, pain management, prognostic assessment, and palliative care integration. Excludes primary CNS lymphoma (separate template), primary leptomeningeal gliomatosis, and isolated parenchymal brain metastases without leptomeningeal involvement (see Brain Metastases template).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline hematologic function; chemotherapy candidacy; thrombocytopenia (LP safety, IT chemo); leukocytosis suggesting concurrent infection; lymphopenia from prior treatment
Essential/Core Labs.target: WBC, ANC, platelets within normal limits; ANC >1500 for IT chemotherapy; platelets >50,000 for LP

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function for methotrexate clearance (IT MTX); hepatic function for systemic therapy dosing; electrolytes (SIADH from CNS disease); glucose for serum:CSF ratio; steroid-induced hyperglycemia
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; anticipate glucose elevation with dexamethasone; creatinine clearance >60 for systemic methotrexate

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy assessment before lumbar puncture; surgical candidacy for Ommaya reservoir placement
Essential/Core Labs.target: INR <1.5 and platelets >50,000 for LP; INR <1.4 for Ommaya placement

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Serum glucose for CSF:serum glucose ratio (low CSF glucose suggests LMD); steroid-induced hyperglycemia baseline
Essential/Core Labs.target: Obtain simultaneously with LP; normal serum glucose; CSF glucose <60% of serum suggests LMD

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Tumor burden marker; elevated in leptomeningeal disease; prognostic marker; CSF LDH also informative
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal serum; elevated suggests high tumor burden

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Required before IT chemotherapy or radiation; beta-hCG-secreting tumors (rare); treatment planning
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if elevated, consider choriocarcinoma or germ cell tumor as primary

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Unknown primary evaluation; breast (CA 15-3, CEA), ovarian (CA 125), GI (CEA, CA 19-9), germ cell (AFP); can also be measured in CSF for comparison
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Elevations guide primary site evaluation; CSF tumor markers may be elevated in LMD even when serum is normal

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Immunosuppression assessment affecting treatment options; primary CNS lymphoma differential; reactivation risk with immunosuppressive therapy
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive requires hepatitis prophylaxis before chemotherapy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Infection differential (bacterial or fungal meningitis vs. neoplastic meningitis); inflammatory markers
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated may suggest concurrent infection

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Tumor lysis risk in hematologic malignancies with high CSF cell counts; baseline before IT chemotherapy
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated in hematologic malignancies with high tumor burden

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Required 24-48h after IT methotrexate if concurrent systemic methotrexate; toxicity monitoring; delayed clearance risk
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Undetectable at 48h; elevated levels require leucovorin rescue

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Fatigue differential; hypothyroidism from prior immunotherapy (checkpoint inhibitors); pituitary metastasis
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; abnormal may indicate thyroid dysfunction from immunotherapy

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Emerging diagnostic tool; sensitivity ~80-90% for LMD (higher than cytology); can detect actionable mutations in CSF; monitor treatment response via serial cfDNA levels
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Detectable tumor-specific mutations; concordance with primary tumor molecular profile; declining cfDNA suggests treatment response

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Identify actionable mutations in CSF when tissue biopsy not feasible; EGFR, ALK, HER2, BRAF, PIK3CA; guide targeted therapy selection
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Actionable driver mutations; may differ from primary tumor (clonal evolution)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Elevated in LMD; may serve as biomarker for disease activity; research tool; correlates with clinical outcomes
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Elevated (>10 pg/mL suggests LMD); declining levels may indicate treatment response

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If clinical presentation includes features of paraneoplastic syndrome (limbic encephalitis, cerebellar degeneration) coexisting with LMD
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; positive identifies concurrent paraneoplastic syndrome requiring different treatment approach

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Complementary to CSF cfDNA; systemic disease monitoring; may guide systemic therapy when CSF sampling not feasible
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Detectable mutations guide therapy; monitor systemic disease burden

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated ICP common in LMD (30-50% of patients); communicating hydrocephalus assessment; guides need for CSF diversion
Lumbar Puncture.target: 10-20 cm H2O normal; >25 cm H2O elevated; >30 cm H2O consider urgent CSF diversion

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: GOLD STANDARD for definitive LMD diagnosis; sensitivity ~50% on single LP, improves to ~80-90% with 2-3 repeat LPs; MUST process within 30 minutes (cells degrade rapidly)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Malignant cells present = diagnostic (100% specific); negative does NOT exclude LMD; report includes morphology and cell type

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Higher sensitivity than cytology for hematologic malignancies (lymphoma, leukemia); identifies clonal B-cell or T-cell populations; useful even when cytology is negative
Lumbar Puncture.target: Monoclonal B-cell or aberrant T-cell population; clonal immunoglobulin light chain restriction; abnormal immunophenotype

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in >80% of LMD patients; nonspecific but supports diagnosis; monitor treatment response
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal 15-45 mg/dL; elevated >50 mg/dL in most LMD; markedly elevated (>100 mg/dL) common; declining with treatment = good sign

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low CSF glucose (hypoglycorrhachia) present in ~40-60% of LMD; calculate CSF:serum ratio
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal CSF glucose >40 mg/dL (or >60% of serum); low CSF glucose (<40 or CSF:serum <0.5) supports LMD diagnosis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Lymphocytic pleocytosis in 40-70% of LMD; distinguish from infectious meningitis; atypical cells on differential
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC <5 normal; elevated WBC with lymphocytic predominance supports LMD; atypical or malignant cells on differential

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in LMD; marker of tumor cell turnover in CSF; prognostic; monitor treatment response
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal CSF LDH <40 U/L; elevated supports LMD; very high levels associated with worse prognosis

Lumbar Puncture.item: CSF tumor markers (CEA, CA 15-3, AFP as guided by primary)
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: May be elevated in CSF even when cytology is negative; supports diagnosis; monitor treatment response
Lumbar Puncture.target: CSF:serum ratio >1 for tumor markers highly suggestive of LMD; declining with treatment = response

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rule out concurrent infectious meningitis (bacterial, fungal); Ommaya reservoir infection
Lumbar Puncture.target: No organisms; positive culture = concurrent infection requiring treatment before IT chemo

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: If immunocompromised or clinical suspicion for fungal/TB meningitis mimicking LMD

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate in ED for acute presentation
Essential/First-line.target: Mass effect, hydrocephalus (communicating or obstructive), hemorrhage; determines LP safety; midline shift assessment
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Pregnancy (benefit outweighs risk in acute setting)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without gadolinium (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h; GOLD STANDARD for LMD diagnosis; thin-cut (1mm) 3D T1 post-contrast and FLAIR sequences
Essential/First-line.target: Leptomeningeal enhancement (linear, nodular, or combined); cranial nerve enhancement (CN III, V, VII, VIII most common); subependymal enhancement; communicating hydrocephalus; concurrent parenchymal metastases
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h; essential for complete staging; cauda equina and nerve root involvement
Essential/First-line.target: Leptomeningeal enhancement along spinal cord surface; nerve root thickening and enhancement (especially cauda equina); intradural nodular deposits; cord compression from epidural extension

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 48h if primary unknown or restaging needed
Essential/First-line.target: Primary tumor identification; systemic disease burden; additional metastatic sites; guides systemic treatment options
Lung primary (most common solid tumor causing LMD along with breast); pulmonary metastases; aspiration pneumonia if obtunded

Extended.timing: During hospitalization or outpatient; systemic staging
Extended.target: Primary tumor; additional metastatic disease; leptomeningeal FDG uptake (low sensitivity for LMD but helps identify systemic disease burden)

Extended.timing: If MRI contraindicated; intrathecal contrast via LP
Extended.target: Filling defects in subarachnoid space; nodular deposits; blockage of CSF flow; nerve root clumping
Extended.contraindications: Same as LP contraindications; contrast allergy

Extended.timing: Before initiating IT chemotherapy; determines CSF flow dynamics
Extended.target: Normal CSF flow pattern; ABNORMAL flow (block at skull base, spinal block, ventricular outlet obstruction) present in 30-70% of LMD patients; blocked flow predicts poor IT chemo distribution and increased toxicity

Extended.timing: If visual symptoms or suspected optic nerve/orbital involvement
Extended.target: Optic nerve enhancement; orbital soft tissue involvement; perineural spread along CN V
QTc for antiemetics and targeted therapies; cardiac function baseline

Rare/Advanced.timing: When standard MRI equivocal; higher sensitivity for subtle leptomeningeal disease
Rare/Advanced.target: Subarachnoid FLAIR hyperintensity indicating protein-rich CSF or tumor; more sensitive than T1 post-contrast for early/subtle LMD
Catheter tip position in frontal horn of lateral ventricle; no hemorrhage; no air-fluid level concerning for infection

Rare/Advanced.timing: When CSF cytology repeatedly negative despite high clinical suspicion and classic MRI findings
Rare/Advanced.target: Tissue diagnosis confirming leptomeningeal carcinomatosis; histopathology and molecular profiling
Rare/Advanced.contraindications: Coagulopathy; lesion not safely accessible; poor performance status precluding surgery

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Vasogenic edema from leptomeningeal disease; symptomatic relief of headache, nausea, cranial neuropathies; bridge to definitive treatment

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV/PO q6h; moderate symptoms 4-8 mg/day; severe symptoms/herniation 10 mg IV then 4-8 mg q6h (up to 16-24 mg/day); begin taper once definitive treatment initiated; GI prophylaxis with PPI while on steroids

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes (relative); GI bleeding (relative); psychosis from prior steroids
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Glucose q6h (steroid hyperglycemia); mental status; blood pressure; GI symptoms; signs of infection (immunosuppression)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Active seizures in setting of leptomeningeal disease with cortical irritation

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV push (max 4 mg per dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total; bridge to AED loading

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression without ventilator support; acute narrow-angle glaucoma
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Respiratory status; sedation level; oxygen saturation; blood pressure

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: AED loading after benzodiazepine for seizure in LMD; preferred AED in cancer (no CYP interactions with chemotherapy or targeted agents)

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV over 15 min; avoid phenytoin/fosphenytoin if possible (CYP interactions with chemotherapy and targeted agents); transition to oral 500-1500 mg BID for maintenance

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust if CrCl <50); known hypersensitivity
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Seizure recurrence; renal function for dose adjustment; behavioral changes

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute hydrocephalus with herniation signs (pupil asymmetry, posturing, declining GCS)

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus over 15-20 min; may repeat 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h; bridge to emergent CSF diversion or radiation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: CHF; severe renal failure; anuria; severe dehydration
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Serum osmolality (keep <320 mOsm/kg); BMP q6h; urine output; ICP if monitored; renal function

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute herniation from obstructive hydrocephalus due to LMD when mannitol contraindicated or insufficient

dosing.instructions: 23.4% NaCl 30 mL via central line over 15 min (MUST be central line); alternative: 3% NaCl 250 mL over 30 min (can be peripheral); bridge to emergent CSF diversion

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Hypernatremia (Na >160); central pontine myelinolysis risk; 23.4% requires central line
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Sodium q2-4h; serum osmolality; neurologic exam; target Na 145-155 mEq/L

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute obstructive hydrocephalus with declining level of consciousness from LMD blocking CSF pathways

dosing.instructions: Emergent neurosurgical consultation for external ventricular drain placement; temporary CSF diversion; can measure ICP continuously

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Coagulopathy (correct first); scalp infection at insertion site
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: ICP monitoring (target <20 mmHg); CSF output; infection surveillance (daily CSF cell count if prolonged)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: CNS malignancy with high VTE risk (20-30%); immobility from neurologic deficits

dosing.instructions: Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily starting within 24-48h unless contraindicated; SCDs immediately on admission; hold 24h before and after LP or IT chemo

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Active intracranial hemorrhage; planned LP within 12h; planned Ommaya surgery; CrCl <30 (use heparin instead)
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Platelet count; signs of hemorrhage; anti-Xa levels if renal impairment

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: VTE prophylaxis when enoxaparin contraindicated (renal impairment CrCl <30)

dosing.instructions: Heparin 5000 units SC q8h; hold 4h before and after LP or IT chemo; SCDs as adjunct

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Active intracranial hemorrhage; planned LP within 4h; planned Ommaya surgery; HIT history
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Platelet count (HIT surveillance); signs of hemorrhage

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: GI protection while on dexamethasone; critical illness with steroid use

dosing.instructions: Omeprazole 20 mg PO daily or pantoprazole 40 mg IV daily if NPO; continue throughout steroid course

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Known hypersensitivity; consider C. difficile risk with prolonged PPI use
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: GI symptoms; consider H. pylori testing if prolonged use

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: First-line IT chemotherapy for LMD from solid tumors (breast, lung); best evidence base among IT agents

dosing.instructions: 12 mg in 3-5 mL preservative-free normal saline via Ommaya reservoir; twice weekly for 4 weeks (induction), then weekly for 4 weeks (consolidation), then monthly (maintenance); co-administer leucovorin 10 mg PO q6h x 4 doses starting 24h after each IT dose to prevent systemic toxicity

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent high-dose systemic methotrexate (combined toxicity); pre-existing severe leukoencephalopathy; active CNS infection; blocked CSF flow (perform flow study first — blocked flow increases neurotoxicity)
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: CBC before each dose; renal function (methotrexate clearance); neurologic exam (chemical meningitis, leukoencephalopathy); MRI q6-8 weeks for response and leukoencephalopathy surveillance

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: IT chemotherapy when Ommaya reservoir not yet placed; initial treatment while awaiting surgery

dosing.instructions: 12 mg in 3-5 mL preservative-free normal saline injected slowly via LP; patient lies flat for 1 hour post-injection; same schedule as Ommaya administration; Ommaya preferred for repeated dosing (avoids repeat LPs, more reliable CSF distribution)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Concurrent high-dose systemic methotrexate; pre-existing severe leukoencephalopathy; active CNS infection; blocked CSF flow; coagulopathy; mass effect; skin infection at LP site
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: CBC before each dose; renal function; neurologic exam; monitor for post-LP headache; CSF leak at puncture site

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Alternative or second-line IT agent; sustained-release formulation allows less frequent dosing; solid tumors and hematologic malignancies

dosing.instructions: 50 mg liposomal cytarabine (DepoCyt) IT via Ommaya or LP q2 weeks for 5 doses (induction), then q4 weeks (maintenance); co-administer dexamethasone 4 mg PO BID for 5 days starting day of injection (prevents chemical arachnoiditis); NOTE: DepoCyt supply has been intermittent — verify availability

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Known hypersensitivity; active meningeal infection; blocked CSF flow
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: CBC before each dose; neurologic exam (chemical arachnoiditis occurs in 20-40% without dex prophylaxis); lumbar symptoms; fever; MRI q6-8 weeks

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Third-line IT agent; used when methotrexate and cytarabine not tolerated or disease refractory; breast cancer LMD

dosing.instructions: 10 mg in 3-5 mL preservative-free normal saline via Ommaya reservoir; twice weekly during induction; taper to weekly then monthly per response

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Active infection; severe myelosuppression (ANC <500); blocked CSF flow
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: CBC (myelosuppression more common than with MTX); neurologic exam; renal function

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Repeated IT chemotherapy delivery; avoids multiple lumbar punctures; more reliable drug distribution to ventricles and subarachnoid space; can also be used for CSF drainage

dosing.instructions: Neurosurgery for subcutaneous reservoir connected to ventricular catheter; catheter tip in frontal horn of ipsilateral lateral ventricle; post-op CT to confirm placement before use; typically ready for use 48-72h post-placement

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Coagulopathy (INR >1.4, platelets <100,000); overlying scalp infection; severe hydrocephalus (may need VP shunt instead); very poor performance status (KPS <40) precluding surgery
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Post-op CT for catheter position; wound site (infection, CSF leak); daily neurologic checks post-op; long-term: site infection surveillance at each access

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Symptomatic bulky leptomeningeal disease; cranial nerve deficits; cauda equina syndrome; CSF flow block requiring focal radiation to restore flow

dosing.instructions: Focal RT to symptomatic sites; typically 30 Gy in 10 fractions to affected region; may treat cranial nerves, cauda equina, or sites of CSF block; concurrent IT chemo if CSF flow adequate

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Prior radiation to same field (cumulative dose limits); very poor performance status; extensive disease making focal approach impractical
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Neurologic exam; MRI post-radiation (6-8 weeks); blood counts if concurrent chemotherapy; late effects (radiation necrosis, myelopathy)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Diffuse cerebral leptomeningeal disease; concurrent multiple parenchymal brain metastases; symptomatic cranial neuropathies not responsive to steroids

dosing.instructions: Standard: 30 Gy in 10 fractions (3 Gy/fraction); poor prognosis: 20 Gy in 5 fractions; hippocampal avoidance (HA-WBRT) when feasible + memantine; consider concurrent IT chemo (typically given on non-radiation days)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Prior WBRT (re-irradiation has higher toxicity risk); severe leukoencephalopathy; very poor prognosis (KPS <40) where radiation unlikely to provide benefit
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Neurologic exam weekly during treatment; CBC weekly; cognitive function post-treatment; MRI 4-6 weeks post-WBRT; memantine for neuroprotection

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Extensive leptomeningeal disease involving brain and full spinal axis; hematologic malignancies with CSF involvement; selected solid tumors with diffuse leptomeningeal seeding

dosing.instructions: 30-36 Gy to craniospinal axis in 1.5-1.8 Gy fractions; significant myelosuppression expected; requires good performance status (KPS >=60); proton therapy preferred when available (less bone marrow toxicity)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Severe cytopenias (ANC <1000, platelets <75,000); very poor performance status; recent myelosuppressive chemotherapy without adequate recovery; pregnancy
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: CBC 2x/week during treatment; weekly neurologic exam; renal function; esophagitis and nausea management; delayed: myelosuppression nadir at 2-4 weeks post-CSI

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: EGFR-mutant NSCLC with leptomeningeal disease; excellent CSF penetration

dosing.instructions: Osimertinib 80 mg PO daily; CSF penetration ~2-7% (sufficient for activity); may increase to 160 mg daily for LMD per BLOOM trial; continue until progression or intolerance

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Interstitial lung disease/pneumonitis; QTc >500 ms; severe hepatic impairment
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: ECG at baseline and monthly (QTc); LFTs monthly; ophthalmologic exam if visual symptoms; CBC; monitor for pneumonitis

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: ALK-rearranged NSCLC with leptomeningeal disease; highest CNS penetration among ALK inhibitors

dosing.instructions: Lorlatinib 100 mg PO daily; alternative: alectinib 600 mg PO BID; intracranial response rates 60-80%

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent strong CYP3A inducers; hyperlipidemia; CNS effects (mood, cognition)
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Lipid panel monthly; LFTs monthly; neuropsychiatric assessment; ECG; CBC

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: HER2-positive breast cancer with leptomeningeal disease; small molecule with CNS penetration

dosing.instructions: Tucatinib 300 mg PO BID + trastuzumab (IV per schedule) + capecitabine 1000 mg/m2 PO BID days 1-14 q21d; per HER2CLIMB trial; trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd) 5.4 mg/kg IV q3wk is alternative (DESTINY-Breast03 CNS data)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; capecitabine: DPD deficiency (fatal toxicity); severe renal impairment
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: LFTs q2 weeks x 8 weeks then monthly; CBC q3 weeks; hand-foot syndrome monitoring; diarrhea assessment; cardiac function (LVEF q3 months)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Melanoma with leptomeningeal disease; immunotherapy combination has best intracranial activity

dosing.instructions: Ipilimumab 3 mg/kg + nivolumab 1 mg/kg IV q3 weeks for 4 cycles, then nivolumab 480 mg IV q4 weeks maintenance; BRAF+ melanoma: dabrafenib 150 mg BID + trametinib 2 mg daily is alternative (faster response); response rate for LMD is lower than parenchymal disease

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic immunosuppression (relative); solid organ transplant; concurrent high-dose steroids (>10 mg prednisone equivalent — reduces immunotherapy efficacy)
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: irAE monitoring (hepatic, thyroid, adrenal, colitis, pneumonitis, dermatitis); LFTs and TSH before each cycle; glucose; lipase; neurologic exam for immune-related neurotoxicity

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Lymphomatous or leukemic meningitis; high-dose systemic methotrexate achieves therapeutic CSF levels

dosing.instructions: High-dose methotrexate 3.5 g/m2 IV over 4h with leucovorin rescue; alternatively, high-dose cytarabine 3 g/m2 IV q12h x 4-6 doses; ibrutinib (for CLL/mantle cell) or lenalidomide (for DLBCL) may have CNS activity; coordinate with hematology/oncology

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Renal impairment (creatinine clearance <60); third-space fluid collections; concurrent NSAIDs or PPIs (impair MTX clearance); mucositis
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: MTX levels q6h until <0.05 mcM; aggressive IV hydration (3 L/m2/day); urine alkalinization (pH >7); renal function; CBC; mucositis

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.indication: Symptomatic communicating hydrocephalus from LMD not responsive to medical management; persistent elevated ICP despite steroids and diuretics; improves quality of life and enables IT chemotherapy

dosing.instructions: Neurosurgical VP shunt placement; programmable valve preferred (allows pressure adjustments); consider Ommaya reservoir placement at same surgery if IT chemo planned; filter may be considered to prevent peritoneal tumor seeding (controversial efficacy)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.contraindications: Active CNS or systemic infection; severe coagulopathy; peritoneal carcinomatosis (relative — use VA or VPL shunt instead); high CSF protein causing frequent shunt obstruction
Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Post-op CT for catheter position; valve pressure optimization; shunt function assessment; infection surveillance; peritoneal seeding monitoring (theoretical risk)

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Post-seizure maintenance; cortical irritation from leptomeningeal disease; preferred AED in cancer (no CYP interactions with chemotherapy)

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg PO/IV BID; titrate to seizure control (max 1500 mg BID); renal dose adjustment if CrCl <50; IV available if NPO

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Seizure recurrence; behavioral changes (irritability, depression); renal function for dose adjustment

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Symptom management transition from acute IV to oral; taper as definitive treatment initiated

dosing.instructions: Taper from 16 mg/day: 16 to 12 to 8 to 6 to 4 to 2 to 1 to off, reducing every 3-5 days; slower taper if symptoms recur; minimum effective dose long-term; monitor for adrenal insufficiency if >3 weeks

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.contraindications: Inability to taper due to symptoms (consider radiation to enable taper); adrenal suppression after prolonged use
Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Blood glucose (daily on steroids); weight; mental status (steroid psychosis); proximal weakness (steroid myopathy); cushingoid features; bone density if prolonged

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Adjunctive ICP reduction; mild communicating hydrocephalus; headache from elevated CSF pressure when surgical CSF diversion not indicated or not yet available

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg PO BID; may increase to 250 mg TID or 500 mg BID; max 2 g/day; reduces CSF production by 50%

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.contraindications: Severe hepatic insufficiency; sulfonamide allergy; severe metabolic acidosis; hyponatremia; hypokalemia
Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: BMP (metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia); renal function; symptoms of ICP (headache, vision); tingling in extremities (common, benign)

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Nausea and vomiting from elevated ICP, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy

dosing.instructions: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea/vomiting; use around the clock during IT chemotherapy and radiation; dexamethasone itself provides anti-emetic effect

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.contraindications: QTc prolongation (check ECG if risk factors); serotonin syndrome with concurrent serotonergic agents; severe hepatic impairment (max 8 mg/day)
Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: QTc if multiple QT-prolonging medications; constipation; headache

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Prevents systemic methotrexate toxicity from IT methotrexate absorbed systemically; mandatory with each IT MTX dose

dosing.instructions: Leucovorin 10 mg PO q6h for 4 doses starting 24 hours after each IT methotrexate administration; increase to 25 mg q6h if elevated serum MTX levels; continue until serum MTX level <0.05 microM

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Serum methotrexate level at 24h and 48h if concurrent systemic MTX; CBC; mucositis; diarrhea

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Prolonged dexamethasone (>20 mg/week) combined with chemotherapy or immunosuppressive therapy

dosing.instructions: TMP-SMX 1 DS tablet PO Monday/Wednesday/Friday; alternative if sulfa allergic: atovaquone 1500 mg PO daily or dapsone 100 mg PO daily (check G6PD first)

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.contraindications: Sulfa allergy; G6PD deficiency (for dapsone alternative); severe renal impairment; megaloblastic anemia from folate deficiency
Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: CBC (leukopenia from TMP-SMX); renal function; rash; GI symptoms

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Steroid-induced osteoporosis prevention; expected prolonged steroid course

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg/day + Vitamin D3 800-1000 IU/day; divided dosing improves absorption; take with meals

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Serum calcium; 25-OH Vitamin D level; renal function

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Headache from elevated ICP or meningeal irritation; first-line analgesic; avoid NSAIDs with concurrent methotrexate

dosing.instructions: Acetaminophen 650-1000 mg PO q6h; max 4 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment); dexamethasone often most effective for LMD headache; avoid NSAIDs if concurrent methotrexate (impairs clearance) or thrombocytopenia

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.contraindications: Hepatic impairment (max 2 g/day); severe hepatic failure
Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Pain scores q4h; hepatic function if prolonged use

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Radicular pain from nerve root involvement (cauda equina); neuropathic pain from cranial neuropathies

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg PO at bedtime; titrate by 300 mg/day every 3 days to 300-900 mg TID; max 3600 mg/day; renal dose adjustment if CrCl <60

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; renal function for dose adjustment

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Moderate to severe headache or radicular pain not responsive to acetaminophen and gabapentin

dosing.instructions: Morphine 2-4 mg IV q4h PRN severe pain; titrate to pain control; start bowel regimen (docusate 100 mg BID + senna) concurrently; avoid NSAIDs with IT MTX or thrombocytopenia

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.contraindications: Respiratory depression; obtundation; severe hepatic impairment; concurrent CNS depressants (dose reduce)
Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Pain scores q4h; sedation level; respiratory rate (hold if RR <10); constipation; bowel regimen compliance

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Moderate to severe pain for patients tolerating oral medications; transition from IV opioids

dosing.instructions: Oxycodone 5-10 mg PO q4-6h PRN; titrate to pain control; start bowel regimen concurrently; avoid NSAIDs with IT MTX or thrombocytopenia

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.contraindications: Respiratory depression; obtundation; severe hepatic impairment; concurrent CNS depressants
Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Pain scores q4h; sedation level; respiratory status; constipation; bowel regimen compliance

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Cognitive neuroprotection during whole-brain radiation therapy

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily x 1 week, then 5 mg BID x 1 week, then 10 mg AM + 5 mg PM x 1 week, then 10 mg BID; continue for 6 months total; start day 1 of WBRT

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Cognitive function monitoring; renal function; dizziness; confusion

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.indication: Hyperglycemia management in patients on high-dose dexamethasone; occurs in 50-60% of steroid-treated patients

dosing.instructions: Fingerstick glucose q6h; sliding scale insulin initially; transition to basal-bolus if persistent >180 mg/dL (typically need 2-3x baseline insulin requirements); glucose peaks 4-8 hours after steroid dose; anticipate insulin needs decrease as steroids taper

Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.contraindications: Hypoglycemia risk (especially as steroids taper — adjust insulin promptly)
Adjunctive/Supportive Treatment.monitoring: Fingerstick glucose q6h (q1h if insulin drip); HbA1c monthly if prolonged steroids; hypoglycemia symptoms; adjust insulin as steroid dose changes

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.item: IT chemotherapy with blocked CSF flow
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Blocked CSF flow (verified by radionuclide flow study) leads to poor drug distribution and markedly increased neurotoxicity from drug accumulation

dosing.instructions: Do NOT administer IT chemotherapy until CSF flow study confirms normal flow or radiation clears obstruction
dosing.orderSentence: IT chemotherapy with blocked CSF flow - IT - see dosing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.pretreatment: CSF flow study (In-111 DTPA) required before initiating IT chemotherapy
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Blocked CSF flow; administer focal radiation to site of block first, then repeat flow study before starting IT chemo
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Chemical meningitis; leukoencephalopathy; myelopathy if drug pools at block site

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Preservatives (benzyl alcohol, methylparaben) are directly neurotoxic when administered intrathecally; can cause fatal chemical arachnoiditis

dosing.instructions: ALL IT medications must be preservative-free; only preservative-free normal saline for reconstitution
dosing.orderSentence: Preservative-containing solutions via IT route - IT - see dosing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.pretreatment: Pharmacy verification of preservative-free status for every IT preparation
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: ANY preservative-containing solution is ABSOLUTELY CONTRAINDICATED intrathecally
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Acute chemical meningitis; seizures; death if preservative administered IT

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: CYP enzyme induction reduces efficacy of many chemotherapy agents, targeted therapies, and dexamethasone

dosing.instructions: Use levetiracetam, lacosamide, or valproic acid instead (non-enzyme-inducing); if already on phenytoin, transition to levetiracetam
dosing.orderSentence: Enzyme-inducing AEDs (phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital) - PO - see dosing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.pretreatment: Review all drug interactions with oncology team
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Concurrent use with temozolomide, irinotecan, many targeted agents; reduce dexamethasone efficacy
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Seizure control during transition; AED levels

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: NSAIDs reduce renal clearance of methotrexate, increasing systemic toxicity risk even with IT administration

dosing.instructions: Avoid ibuprofen, naproxen, ketorolac while receiving IT or systemic methotrexate; use acetaminophen for pain
dosing.orderSentence: NSAIDs (concurrent with methotrexate) - PO - see dosing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.pretreatment: Review all medications for MTX interactions
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Concurrent IT or systemic methotrexate use; thrombocytopenia

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.item: Lumbar puncture with obstructive hydrocephalus or significant mass effect
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Risk of transtentorial or tonsillar herniation if LP performed with obstructive hydrocephalus or significant mass effect from concurrent parenchymal metastases

dosing.instructions: Obtain CT head before LP; if obstructive hydrocephalus present, obtain neurosurgery consult for EVD before LP
dosing.orderSentence: Lumbar puncture with obstructive hydrocephalus or significant mass effect - - - see dosing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.pretreatment: CT head demonstrating no obstructive hydrocephalus and no midline shift >5mm
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Obstructive hydrocephalus; midline shift >5mm; large posterior fossa mass
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Neurologic exam post-LP; immediate imaging if clinical decline

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.item: High-dose systemic methotrexate concurrent with IT methotrexate
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Combined systemic and intrathecal methotrexate increases risk of severe leukoencephalopathy and myelosuppression

dosing.instructions: Coordinate timing with oncology; do not give IT MTX within 24-48h of systemic MTX without methotrexate level clearance
dosing.orderSentence: High-dose systemic methotrexate concurrent with IT methotrexate - IV/IT - see dosing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.pretreatment: Serum methotrexate levels must be <0.05 microM before IT dosing
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Serum MTX levels; CBC; neurologic exam; MRI for leukoencephalopathy

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurosurgery consultation for Ommaya reservoir placement and possible VP shunt
Neuro-oncology consultation for treatment planning and coordination
Radiation oncology consultation for involved-field RT, WBRT, or craniospinal irradiation
Medical oncology consultation for systemic therapy with CNS penetration
Goals of care and prognosis discussion with patient and family
Palliative care consultation for symptom management and goals of care facilitation

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: CSF flow study before IT chemotherapy initiation
Re-biopsy or CSF sampling for molecular evolution

differential.features: Acute onset; high fever; nuchal rigidity; toxic appearance; CSF with neutrophilic pleocytosis, very low glucose, very high protein, positive Gram stain; rapid deterioration; no history of malignancy typically
differential.tests: CSF Gram stain and culture (positive); CSF WBC typically >1000 with neutrophil predominance; blood cultures; procalcitonin; CRP markedly elevated; rapid clinical response to antibiotics

differential.features: Subacute onset (days to weeks); basilar meningitis on MRI; cranial neuropathies (similar to LMD); CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose, high protein; endemic exposure; immunocompromised
differential.tests: CSF AFB smear and culture (low sensitivity ~10-30%); CSF adenosine deaminase (ADA >10 U/L); TB PCR (GeneXpert); chest X-ray (miliary pattern); TST/IGRA; basal cistern enhancement pattern on MRI

differential.features: Immunocompromised host (HIV, transplant); subacute headache and confusion; elevated ICP; basilar meningitis; cranial neuropathies possible
differential.tests: CSF cryptococcal antigen (high sensitivity); CSF fungal culture; serum cryptococcal antigen; CSF India ink (low sensitivity); Coccidioides CF antibody; CSF opening pressure often very high

differential.features: Leptomeningeal enhancement on MRI (can mimic LMD); cranial neuropathies (especially CN VII); young adults; no malignancy history; systemic sarcoidosis features (hilar lymphadenopathy, skin, eyes)
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar lymphadenopathy); serum ACE (low sensitivity); CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein; gallium or PET scan; tissue biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas; no malignant cells on CSF cytology

differential.features: Multifocal neurologic deficits; headache; cognitive decline; leptomeningeal enhancement possible; beading/irregularity of cerebral vessels on angiography
differential.tests: MR angiography or conventional angiography (vessel beading); CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein; ESR/CRP elevated; leptomeningeal/brain biopsy; ANA, ANCA, complement levels

differential.features: Periventricular enhancing lesions; may have secondary leptomeningeal involvement; immunocompromised patients; dramatic response to corticosteroids ("ghost tumor"); CSF cytology or flow cytometry shows clonal lymphocytes
differential.tests: CSF flow cytometry (clonal B-cells); MRI pattern (periventricular, homogeneous enhancement); biopsy (DO NOT give steroids before biopsy if possible); slit-lamp exam for vitreous involvement; HIV test

differential.features: Acute onset; fever; headache; photophobia; CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis with normal glucose; self-limited (most viral causes); no malignancy history
differential.tests: CSF viral PCR panel (HSV, VZV, enterovirus); CSF cell count (lymphocytic but typically less elevated than bacterial); normal or mildly elevated protein; normal glucose (unlike LMD); clinical improvement over days

differential.features: Subacute cognitive decline, seizures, psychiatric symptoms; may have leptomeningeal enhancement; can coexist with or be triggered by underlying malignancy
differential.tests: Paraneoplastic antibody panel (serum and CSF); CSF: mild pleocytosis, elevated protein, oligoclonal bands; MRI: limbic/temporal signal changes; EEG abnormalities; whole-body PET to identify occult malignancy

differential.features: History of recent neurosurgical procedure, LP, IT chemotherapy, or myelography; headache, fever, neck stiffness; CSF: neutrophilic pleocytosis but sterile cultures
differential.tests: Temporal relationship to procedure (onset within hours to days); CSF cultures negative (critical distinction); CSF glucose usually normal or mildly reduced; self-resolving; dexamethasone responsive

differential.features: Dura-based enhancing lesions on MRI; may mimic meningioma; mass effect; breast and prostate cancer most common dural metastases; CSF cytology negative
differential.tests: MRI: dural-based enhancement (pachymeningeal) rather than pial/leptomeningeal; CT may show bone involvement; CSF cytology typically negative; biopsy for tissue diagnosis if needed

differential.diagnosis: Rapid decline in consciousness (GCS drop >2 points)
differential.features: Acute hydrocephalus; herniation; hemorrhage into tumor
differential.tests: STAT CT head; neurosurgery STAT for EVD if hydrocephalus; escalate to ICU

differential.diagnosis: New bilateral leg weakness or urinary retention
differential.features: Cauda equina syndrome from LMD; spinal cord compression
differential.tests: STAT MRI whole spine; dexamethasone 10 mg IV; neurosurgery and radiation oncology STAT

differential.features: Optic nerve involvement from LMD; papilledema from elevated ICP; pituitary metastasis
differential.tests: STAT ophthalmology; CT head (hydrocephalus); MRI brain with orbital cuts; consider emergent LP for ICP if safe

differential.diagnosis: New cranial neuropathies (facial weakness, diplopia, hearing loss, dysphagia)
differential.features: Progressive LMD; treatment failure; may require change in therapy or urgent radiation
differential.tests: MRI brain with thin cuts through cranial nerves; reassess treatment plan; consider involved-field radiation to affected cranial nerves

differential.features: Chemical meningitis (common) vs. Ommaya reservoir infection (dangerous); bacterial meningitis from immunosuppression
differential.tests: Blood cultures; CSF sampling from Ommaya (cell count, Gram stain, culture); if unable to distinguish, empiric antibiotics until cultures finalize; chemical meningitis typically self-limited (24-72h)

differential.features: Cortical irritation from LMD; metabolic derangement; concurrent parenchymal disease
differential.tests: Benzodiazepines STAT; levetiracetam load; CT head; correct metabolic abnormalities; continuous EEG; see Status Epilepticus template

differential.diagnosis: Severe headache with Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations)
differential.features: Impending herniation from acute hydrocephalus or massive leptomeningeal tumor burden
differential.tests: STAT CT; neurosurgery for emergent EVD; mannitol or hypertonic saline; intubation if GCS <=8; ICU transfer

evidence.evidenceLevel: [NCCN Central Nervous System Cancers](https://www.nccn.org/guidelines/guidelines-detail?category=1&id=1425)
[Le Rhun et al. Ann Oncol 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28881917/)
[Chamberlain et al. Neuro Oncol 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28039364/)
IT methotrexate vs. IT thiotepa for LMD: no significant difference in survival; overall median survival 15.9 weeks with IT chemo
evidence.source: Established IT methotrexate and thiotepa as equivalent first-line IT agents; demonstrated modest benefit of IT chemotherapy

evidence.evidenceLevel: Liposomal cytarabine (DepoCyt) vs. methotrexate for LMD: liposomal cytarabine had longer time to neurologic progression (58 vs. 30 days) and higher cytologic response; less frequent dosing schedule
evidence.source: Established liposomal cytarabine as alternative to methotrexate with more convenient dosing; demonstrated importance of cytologic response

evidence.evidenceLevel: IT chemotherapy added to RT did not improve survival vs. RT alone in breast cancer LMD
evidence.source: Questioned benefit of IT chemotherapy over radiation alone; highlighted need for better agents and patient selection

evidence.evidenceLevel: CSF flow study results predict response to IT chemotherapy: abnormal flow associated with poorer response and increased toxicity
evidence.source: Established CSF flow study as required pre-treatment evaluation before IT chemotherapy

evidence.evidenceLevel: Osimertinib 160 mg daily for EGFR+ NSCLC LMD: response rate 62%; median PFS 8.6 months; CSF concentration therapeutic
evidence.source: Established osimertinib as preferred systemic agent for EGFR+ NSCLC with LMD; may replace IT chemotherapy for this population

evidence.recommendation: [Murthy et al. N Engl J Med 2020 (HER2CLIMB)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31825569/)
evidence.evidenceLevel: Tucatinib + trastuzumab + capecitabine: intracranial response 47%; CNS-PFS 9.9 vs. 4.2 months; includes patients with LMD
evidence.source: Established tucatinib combination for HER2+ breast cancer with brain/leptomeningeal metastases

evidence.recommendation: [Tawbi et al. N Engl J Med 2018 (CheckMate 204)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30134131/)
evidence.evidenceLevel: Ipilimumab + nivolumab in melanoma brain metastases: intracranial response 57% in asymptomatic; LMD cohort response lower but activity demonstrated
evidence.source: Established combination immunotherapy for melanoma CNS disease; some activity in LMD cohort

evidence.evidenceLevel: CSF cell-free DNA (cfDNA) for LMD diagnosis: sensitivity 81% vs. 67% for cytology; can identify actionable mutations and monitor treatment response
evidence.source: Emerging role for CSF liquid biopsy in LMD diagnosis and molecular profiling; may supplement or replace cytology

evidence.evidenceLevel: CSF flow abnormalities in LMD: 30-70% of patients have blocked flow; focal radiation can restore flow in majority; improved IT chemotherapy efficacy after flow restoration
evidence.source: Reinforced importance of pre-treatment CSF flow evaluation; established radiation for flow restoration

evidence.evidenceLevel: HA-WBRT + memantine superior to standard WBRT + memantine for cognitive preservation at 4 and 6 months
evidence.source: HA-WBRT + memantine = new standard when WBRT indicated (applicable to LMD patients requiring WBRT)

evidence.evidenceLevel: Systematic review of LMD prognosis: untreated median survival 4-6 weeks; with treatment median survival 2-4 months; breast cancer LMD has best prognosis among solid tumors (4-6 months); NSCLC and melanoma LMD have shorter survival
evidence.source: Key prognostic reference; guides goals of care discussions; identifies patient subgroups with better prognosis

evidence.evidenceLevel: LMD prognostic factors: good KPS (>=70), single cranial nerve deficit, absence of encephalopathy, CSF cytology conversion to negative, and actionable molecular targets associated with longer survival
evidence.source: Identifies patients most likely to benefit from aggressive treatment vs. those better served by comfort care

monitoring.item: Neurologic checks (GCS, cranial nerves, motor, sensory)
monitoring.frequency: q1-2h in ICU; q2-4h on floor
monitoring.action: STAT CT if decline; neurosurgery for EVD if hydrocephalus; consider dexamethasone increase or emergent radiation
Sliding scale to basal-bolus insulin; typically need 2-3x baseline insulin on dexamethasone; adjust as steroids taper

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor
monitoring.action: Antihypertensives PRN; avoid agents that mask neurologic changes
Hyponatremia (SIADH common with CNS malignancy): fluid restrict if mild; 3% NaCl if <125 or symptomatic; correct no faster than 8 mEq/L per 24h
Escalate analgesics; dexamethasone most effective for LMD headache; consider opioids for moderate-severe; avoid NSAIDs with methotrexate

monitoring.frequency: Continuous observation; consider cEEG if AMS
monitoring.action: Levetiracetam load if first seizure; dose optimization; continuous EEG for unexplained encephalopathy
CSF drainage; osmotherapy; elevate HOB 30 degrees; consider decompressive procedure if refractory

monitoring.item: MRI brain and spine with contrast
monitoring.frequency: q6-8 weeks during active treatment; q3 months during maintenance
monitoring.action: Progressive enhancement: change IT agent, add systemic therapy, add radiation; new disease: reassess treatment plan at tumor board

monitoring.frequency: With each IT chemo cycle; q4-8 weeks
monitoring.action: Persistent positive cytology after 4-6 weeks of IT chemo: switch IT agent; add systemic therapy; consider radiation

monitoring.frequency: Before each IT chemo cycle; weekly during induction
monitoring.action: Hold IT chemo if ANC <1500 or platelets <50,000; growth factor support if needed; dose reduction

monitoring.frequency: Before each IT methotrexate; monthly during systemic therapy
monitoring.action: Dose adjust or hold methotrexate; hydration; nephrology if declining
Hold targeted therapy if ALT/AST >5x ULN; dose reduce per drug-specific guidelines; hepatology if persistent

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit (q1-2 weeks during treatment, q2-4 weeks maintenance)
monitoring.action: New deficits: urgent MRI; reassess treatment response; consider radiation to progressive sites
KPS <40: transition to comfort-focused care; hospice referral; discontinue aggressive treatment
Steroid-dependent symptoms: consider radiation or bevacizumab to enable taper; manage steroid complications
SSRI (sertraline, escitalopram — low CYP interaction); psychology referral; supportive care; palliative care involvement

monitoring.frequency: Each access (q1-2 weeks during IT chemo)
monitoring.action: Suspect infection: aspirate CSF from Ommaya for culture; CT head; empiric antibiotics (vancomycin + cefepime) until culture results; reservoir removal if confirmed infection

disposition.criteria: GCS <=12; signs of herniation (pupil asymmetry, posturing, Cushing triad); acute obstructive hydrocephalus requiring emergent EVD; status epilepticus; respiratory failure from brainstem involvement or neuromuscular weakness; hemodynamic instability; post-Ommaya or VP shunt placement (first 12-24h per institutional protocol)

New diagnosis of LMD requiring workup and treatment initiation; symptomatic hydrocephalus requiring monitoring; initiation of IT chemotherapy (first 1-2 doses for monitoring); post-Ommaya placement (step-down from PACU/ICU); post-seizure requiring AED optimization; rapidly progressive neurologic deficits; severe headache/nausea requiring IV management
Known LMD with mild symptom change; steroid dose adjustment with monitoring; planned same-day IT chemotherapy via established Ommaya with adequate observation
Stable or improving neurologic exam for >=24h; no new cranial neuropathies; no worsening headache or confusion
If hydrocephalus present: VP shunt functioning; symptoms controlled; no evidence of shunt malfunction
IT chemo schedule established; Ommaya functioning if placed; patient and family educated on reservoir care; outpatient IT chemo arrangements confirmed
Seizure-free >=24h on oral AED; therapeutic dosing of levetiracetam established
Headache and pain adequately managed on oral medications
Oral dexamethasone regimen with clear taper schedule; glucose management plan (insulin if needed); PPI prescribed
Safe ambulation (with or without assistive device); safe swallowing; adequate home support or home health arranged

Neuro-oncology (1-2 weeks); radiation oncology (if RT planned, within 1 week); medical oncology (1-2 weeks for systemic therapy); neurosurgery (2 weeks if post-Ommaya or VP shunt); PCP (1 week for steroid monitoring); MRI brain/spine scheduled at 6-8 weeks

Understanding of diagnosis and prognosis; IT chemo schedule and what to expect; signs requiring ED return (acute headache, fever, new weakness, seizure, vision changes, altered consciousness, signs of Ommaya infection); advance care planning discussed; palliative care follow-up if indicated
Code status documented; advance directive discussed; palliative care involvement if appropriate; hospice referral if prognosis very poor and patient/family prefer comfort care
Dose and taper schedule clearly documented; lowest effective dose
Omeprazole 20 mg daily or pantoprazole 40 mg daily while on steroids
If seizure occurred; dose and frequency documented; DO NOT start if no seizure history
Sliding scale or basal-bolus for steroid-induced hyperglycemia; glucometer and supplies; education on adjustment as steroids taper
10 mg PO q6h x 4 doses starting 24h after each IT methotrexate dose (if on IT MTX)
TMP-SMX if on high-dose steroids + chemotherapy
If steroids >2 weeks anticipated
Acetaminophen, gabapentin for neuropathic pain, limited opioid if needed
Ondansetron 4-8 mg q8h PRN
Docusate 100 mg BID if on opioids
